title: Republic. Rob Whitman says 85 percent of immigrants go beyond court hearings.
text: Republic. Rob Whitman, R-1st, says that the process of screening immigrants in the United States on the Mexican border and granting asylum is "floating." Under the laws, immigrants entering the United States can prolong their stay by challenging deportation orders or seeking asylum. They are often given judicial dates to decide their cases and are released in the United States. Most of them go on L, Whitman claims. "You know, 85 percent of them don't show up at the scheduled court hearing or the court schedule," said during a radio interview in November 2 on John Frederick's presentation from Portsmouth. The Whitman Statement comes with thousands of Central American convoys moving through Mexico with the hope of obtaining asylum in the United States. President Donald Trump has deployed 5,600 troops on the United States-Mexico border and ordered the denial of asylum to migrants who do not enter through official border crossings. We wondered whether Whitman was right that 85 per cent of immigrants did not appear in court. The data held by the Ministry of Justice refutes his claim. Twenty-eight percent of the immigrants released in the United States did not attend hearings during the fiscal year that ended on 30 September 2017, according to the latest records of the Department of Justice. Of the 149,436 migrants released in the United States during that period, 41,384 were not allowed to attend. Over a five-year period until the end of September 2017, records show that 23 per cent of undocumented migrants released in the United States did not attend legal hearings. Of the 665,930 migrants released, 151,492 were not present. Not all of these persons have sought asylum. Some of them were unaccompanied children who came to the border, others were immigrants who were already seeking to join their family members in the United States, and many people who did not show up were detained at the border and then released in the United States because, three weeks later, due to severe constraints in immigration courts, they could not access their cases. Asylum-seekers - also known as Assel - were the most cooperative groups; 11 per cent of them did not attend hearings in fiscal year 2017. The records of the Ministry of Justice show that 43,013 persons seeking asylum were scheduled to be heard in court in 2017, and that 4,776 persons did not attend, over a period of five years, 10.1 per cent of the Asilians were not present. 130,092 hearings were scheduled, and 13,130 persons did not attend. Although these figures are high, they are often mentioned. Trump, on October 31, notes at the White House, said "a level like 3%" of immigrants show up for trial. Our judgment said that "85 percent" of immigrants in the United States do not appear in their court hearings. The actual percentage is much lower. Statistics from the Ministry of Justice show that 28 percent of immigrants did not keep their trial dates in 2017, and 11 percent of Isles did not show up. Even a think tank that says that the Ministry of Justice reduces the number of non-offer cases is not close to 85%. Whitman is to be commended for confessing his mistake - the day after we contacted him - in the same radio program in which he made his statement. But his original claim of 85% has been running for years and we're assessing it wrong.
